candidates.title: Replace usages of blocking `reqwest` to be async instead
candidates.body:
The blocking implementation of `reqwest` now uses an internal `tokio`
runtime as of `0.10`. `tokio` doesn't like having nested runtimes, so it
raises an error when `request>=0.10` is used from a tokio-`async`
function.

The primary rationale for continuing to use "blocking" `reqwest` was
because its async implementation was "extremely limited" and didn't
support streamed data from a file.

However, now, we're able to leverage
`tokio::fs::File -> AsyncRead -> ReaderStream -> Body::wrap_stream()`,
which obsoletes this one use case for blocking `reqwest`.

Convert all blocking usages of `reqwest` to `async` accordingly.

candidates.title: Use clang -fminimize-whitespace to increase cache hits.
candidates.body:
Whenever line number differences can be ignored (i.e. when using `-P`), also add `-fminimize-whitespace` to reduce irrelevant formatting differences for hashing. This should allow a cache hit after eg. applying clang-format over the source or editing multi-line comments.

`-fminimize-whitespace` has been [introduced in Clang 14](https://releases.llvm.org/14.0.0/tools/clang/docs/ReleaseNotes.html#new-compiler-flags). This patch only enables it if detecting Clang version 14 or higher, and when not using Apple's flavour of Clang which uses different version numbers.

This is a continuation of #1055 after applying requested changes and rebasing. It contains the original commits by @InnovativeInventor (Thank you!). There are some differences to #1055: The version field of CCompiler is reused. Which flags for preprocessing can be used is passed from `CCompilerImpl.preprocess` to `preprocess_cmd`. Testing with clang-14 is done using a new builder for Ubuntu 22.04; the compiler version is extracted from the `clang --version` output, deliberately different from how sccache determines whether `-fminimize-whitespace` can be used.

candidates.title: Ignore lockfiles of test crates used in the integration tests
candidates.body:
The lockfile was mostly added by accident FWIU, looking at the file history from https://github.com/mozilla/sccache/commits/main/tests/test-crate/Cargo.lock.

One one hand lockfiles are handy in the sense that they lock the version used so there are no surprises but it's such a trivial dependency/setup that I think it's better for now to just ignore them altogether and come back to this if this ever causes a problem.

Fixes #1145

candidates.title: More complete unit tests for Azure Blob Storage backend
candidates.body:
Pull request #1109 introduced key prefix support for the Azure backend, with unit tests for `normalize_key()`, but those tests didn't test whether the Storage impl *actually* used `normalize_key()` when constructing an API request to Azure.

This change makes the unit tests more complete, by testing the Storage impl directly through the use of a mock HTTP server as Azure API endpoint.

candidates.title: Remove outdated badges from Cargo.toml
candidates.body:
- travis-ci and appveyor don't seem to be used anymore.
- The cargo reference now recommends putting badges into
  the Readme file, where we already a github CI badge.

candidates.title: Use different hashing functions for different file types
candidates.body:
> This pull request is a rebased version of #197, originally made by @metajack.

This adds a new special hasher for static libraries, which contain timestamps and other info that prevent them from being cachable in some cases.

candidates.title: Upgrade futures-locks to 0.7.0
candidates.body:
0.7.0 only has 1 significant change that impacts us: RwLock is now only Sync if its inner type is also.

Assists with #1110 in order to get the release out faster (#1019).

candidates.title: Bump sha-1,sha-2 and hmac
candidates.body:
- bumps the three crates and 
- fixes the clippy lints for feature dist-server

candidates.title: Bump the dependencies that are easy to update
candidates.body:
As a first step towards #1110, this PR updates the dependencies as far as possible with:

- no increase of the MSRV
- Only one minor change to code included

The commits should probably be squashed before merging. CI is passing in my fork of sccache.

candidates.title: Parse env-deps from dep-info
candidates.body:
Parse the environment variables (and their values) referenced in rust code via `env!` or `option_env!` from the `dep-info` file and add them to the hash. The `CARGO_` env variables apparently still have to be blanket added to the hash, since they don't appear in the `dep-info` file.

Closes #972 
Closes #804

candidates.title: Migrate to a Tokio 1.0-capable Selenium webdriver crate
candidates.body:
This prunes many dependency crates by not using old reqwest/tokio crates anymore.

Cherry-pick of https://github.com/paritytech/cachepot/pull/125

candidates.title: feat: Update tokio to 1.0
candidates.body: Followup on https://github.com/mozilla/sccache/pull/985 to pull sccache the last little bit into tokio 1.0

candidates.title: Update Cargo.lock to address security advisories
candidates.body:
I'm not very familiar with rust so many I haven't done this correctly, but here's my attempt.

Related: #935

candidates.title: Migrate to stable Future trait, async/await and Tokio 0.2 runtime
candidates.body:
Builds on #945. Rebased and streamlined version of #946 (thanks to @Marwes and @drahnr for doing most of the work!).

This aims to be a somewhat minimal but complete upgrade to stable `Future` trait and async/await.

At first I tried to split the changes into respective commits but I quickly found that that e.g. migrating storages leads to `reqwest` upgrade, which itself causes other places to be upgraded and so on. Rather than artificially setting up boundaries, migrating everything to `futures_03` and `.compat()` everywhere and switching them back in following commits, I figured that this should be probably reviewed as a whole. Let me know if you really prefer to have it split more granularly somehow.

Most notably:
- Upgrades `tokio` to `0.2`, which supports stable `Futures`.
- Migrates from `futures_03::executor::ThreadPool` to regular `tokio::runtime::Runtime`.
  Because Tokio-enabled I/O such as `tokio v0.2` child processes or timeouts all implicitly now need to be spawned in a Tokio context, rather than creating a custom executor that uses `ThreadPool` but polls relevant Tokio-related futures in a context of a separately running runtime, we use a single Tokio runtime everywhere configured with at least the same amount of worker threads as before and with enabled `blocking` feature. This is designed for I/O-bound tasks (rather than CPU-bound ones) and so it fits the existing use case perfectly since we mostly used `spawn_fn` for operations related to disk I/O.
- Updates `reqwest` to 0.10 (and by extension `hyper` to `0.13`), supporting stable `Future`s.
  That's to easily support async/await in regular mode; in distributed compilation we use Tokio runtime now so it's also easier there to use `Future`-enabled reqwest.
- Uses `async_trait` crate to migrate crucial traits like `Storage`, `Client` to async/await.
  This could be skipped in theory but that's mean sticking `Pin<Box<dyn Future<Output = XYZ> + Send + 'lifetime` as a return type everywhere, since `async fn`s in traits are not supported yet due to lack of GATs (see [here](https://smallcultfollowing.com/babysteps/blog/2019/10/26/async-fn-in-traits-are-hard/))
- Migrates from `futures v0.1` chains to async/await whenever possible.


I tried to retain the existing semantics as much as possible and refrain from any non-trivial refactoring to ease the review and to help this land. Let me know if everything is in order and whether you want me to change anything here.

candidates.title: Enable TLS support for Redis
candidates.body: This enables TLS for Redis backends. Tested against an AWS ElastiCache Redis with TLS. I'm a Rust newbie so I don't know if the dependency changes (in `Cargo.lock`) are OK.

repo.name: sccache
repo.description: sccache is ccache with cloud storage

repo.name: sccache
repo.description: Sccache is a ccache-like tool. It is used as a compiler wrapper and avoids compilation when possible. Sccache has the capability to utilize caching in remote storage environments, including various cloud storage options, or alternatively, in local storage.
